qas.question: What can also be provided by foreign aid?
What do international donors do to promote democracy?

answers.text: provide financing to political parties in developing countries

qas.question: What is another common occurrence of international support for a party?

answers.text: Developing links between ideologically linked parties

qas.question: What does the overseas development institute want to do?

answers.text: to increase support to political parties

qas.question: What funding does the Overseas Development Institute like to offer to support democracies?

plausible_answers.text: development of party manifestos, party constitutions and campaigning skills

qas.question: What was used during the Rose Revolution to make it successful?
What does the Georgian party want to increase?
Why does the Georgian party want to increase support to political parties?
What did the Georgian party want to promote by financing political parties in developing countries?

context: In fledgling democracies <a0_0>funding<a0_0/> can also be provided by <b4_0>foreign aid<b4_0/>. International donors <a1_0>provide financing to political parties in developing countries<a1_0/> as a means to promote <b8_0>democracy and good governance<b8_0/>. Support can be purely financial or otherwise. Frequently it is provided as capacity development activities including the <b5_0>development of party manifestos, party constitutions and campaigning skills<b5_0/>. <a2_0>Developing links between ideologically linked parties<a2_0/> is another common feature of international support for a party. Sometimes this can be perceived as directly supporting the political aims of a political party, such as the support of the US government to the Georgian party behind the Rose Revolution. Other donors work on a more neutral basis, where multiple donors provide grants in countries accessible by all parties for various aims defined by the recipients. There have been calls by leading development think-tanks, such as the Overseas Development Institute, <a3_0>to increase <b6_0>support to political parties<b6_0/><a3_0/> as part of developing the capacity to deal with the demands of interest-driven donors <b7_0>to improve governance<b7_0/>.
